commentBody:
Sam, 

AMER has been used as an answer 222 times, of which 58 have been in the Modern Era.  Of those latter occurrences, every one has been as an abbreviation for America(n).

Prior to that, it was only nearly all of of the time, with a very occasional clue referring to the French word for bitter or bitters.

Hardly unusual.

For our foreign and non-sports solvers:

The San Francisco Giants are a professional baseball team in the National League of Major League Baseball.

The New York Giants are a professional football team in the NFL.  

That's why Sam said, "Go west, not east."

(The baseball team originally played in New York as well.)
Band names as clues?  Now that was fun, and added another little spark to a Tuesday puzzle.
Another good puzzle. A little more difficult for me than usual for a Tuesday. Enjoyed the them. Thanks!

What nearly derailed me was persisting in spelling DIARESIS/DIAERESIS/whatever with an A, and having eaten GIMBAP at lunch today, as my local Korean restaurant spells it. But I started out well by figuring out CAROLINA REAPERS immediately, so that made me feel better.
Dieresis threw me off, but I got the themed entries very quickly. Nice Tuesday puzzle
I done did this puzz

Me, staring at GREaKELEMENTS (because "diaeresis" didn't fit so I guessed at diaresis) -- "something isn't right here. ACH." Then I had some FROYO, HUGged an ELECTEE, and GASsed UP my brain a bit. Well, no, none of that, just a bowl of ice cream and some glaring. 

Love having FROYO right above LOVER ... same here...

Nice Natick with IDINA crossing KIMBAP. 

Oh the possibilities between proper names and foreign words are amazingly endless.

Smashing Punpkins: post-Halloween fun?

My Chemical Romance: pheromones?

Panic! at the Disco: fire alarm?

Was just doing a puzzle from the archives that had TANK UP as an answer (26 Mar 2017 for those playing along at home, clue [Get ready for a long drive]), and now GAS UP. 
Do people really say that?

(Here we would say ‚ÄúI need to fill up‚Äù or simply ‚ÄúI need to get petrol/fuel‚Äù but not to my knowledge ‚ÄúI need to petrol up‚Äù. If someone said to me they needed to ‚Äúfuel up‚Äù, I‚Äôd assume they meant they themselves needed to eat something before some exertion, not that their car had an empty tank)

OK, how many of you had POIROT before MARPLE?

How about FOOTBALL players before BASEBALL players?

How about GREEN elements and NIM BAP?

How many of you thought that the Bront√´ sisters used the toilet more frequently than the brothers Grimm because they had DIURESIS? 

How many of you thought, "Nah, it's LA Mancha, like, it's not 'Man of Mancha' bruh." 

Dude. You rock (band) my world!

I'll also mention that I was surprised that for [Green Day], Alex went with SAINT PATRICKS and not an Earth Day answer (not Arbor Day, as his notes say).

Happy Earth Day, all!

I didn't get the happy music when I finished, so I was sure I had messed up in the section with DIERESIS and KIMBAP, as those words looked so odd to me.... but nope, I had  "mecular" instead of SECULAR, oops!

A little trickier than I'm used to for a Tuesday,  but surprisingly I was almost 5 min under my average Tues time.  A speedy solve that actually challenged me at the same time? Perfection!

GASUP at an ESSO, TEXACO, SHELL, MOBIL . . .


Brands, 
exciting and new!
Come aboard, our QTIPS are new
Brands, solver's sweetest reward.
Let the Oatly flow, with Oreos for you.
The Brand grid soon will be making another run
the Brand grid irritates solvers from distant suns.
Stow your ALFA ROMEO,
slide into your hot DIESEL pants
And Brands won't hurt anymore
It's like SARALEE at an IKEA store!

The Brand grid soon will be making another run
The Brand grid promises FROYO for everyone
Set a course with your GARMIN,
Don't forget the MEOWMIX for your cats. 
Brands won't hurt anymore.
An ORALB smile from a HILTON door.
it's Brands! it's Brands! it's Brands!
it's the Brand grid-ah!
Welcome abiard it's Brands, Brands, Brands!

Any puzzle with a Kit KAT Bar in it is okay by me.
I thought the themers were fun.
Thanks for a nicely Toughened Up Tuesday, Alex.
John Travolta will have a hard time completing this puzzle (60A)

Sam, I feel there is a lot of overlap in the Venn diagram of Weird Al fans and They Might Be Guants fans. I saw Weird Al a couple of times when he played at our county fair in the 90s, and I'm looking forward to catching him again this summer, but I've yet to see TMBG live!

Loved this puzzle! I didn't know what to expect when I saw Red Hot Chili Peppers and was nicely surprised. All the themers made me smile, but especially Earth, Wind & Fire, not just for the answer, but also for the memory it evoked. That was the first big arena concert I ever went to, aged 13. My oldest brother was kind enough to let me tag along, and persuasive enough to convince my parents that he would watch over me. Well, he almost had a heart attack when at one point he looked toward my seat and saw I was gone. I needed to use the restroom and simply got up and went to find one, without it ever crossing my mind that I should let him know. (Oh boy, did I get chewed out.) It was an outstanding get-up-and-dance kind of concert, and everyone was on their feet, especially for this: https://youtu.be/r58GQYFZeLE?si=-4cQYVLSL6nmeGYQ But i digress. Thank you, Mr. Eaton-Salners for a very fun and imaginative theme, and for fill that was interesting enough to make it a Terrific Tuesday!
AMER, BRUH, BLAM, LGA, SAO, YUP, MARPLE... Too many pretend words and obscure proper nouns sapped the fun out of this puzzle.

ŒîŒ¥ŒîŒπŒ±ŒØœÅŒµœÉŒ∑ and thus diaeresis 

The phonetic NYT crossword persists üòÄ

When I said, upon finishing that false but extremely trying seven-day streak on Sunday, that I wasn't going to try for any more streaks, it had slipped my mind that Monday and Tuesday were coming right up, so naturally I will extend that streak by two not-so-phony segments. One done.

I will confess that it took me half an hour. (Fifty-nine seconds for the Mini.)

My Cubbies are down in the first, but inning isn't everything.

(But you bat I'm still having a ball.)

Fun Tuesday puzzle with the added treat of inspiring my playlist for the rest of the day.  And yes, I do have music from each on my phone. Funnily though, I owned albums from each band in the day on the medium of the time:  EW&F on vinyl and 8 track (look it up kids), TMBG and RHCP on cassette and GD on CD.

That SW corner... Abbreviation clued with a brand (just... No), a proper name, a Korean dish, a name of a diacricitc mark I've never seen before - all entangled. And why *GREEK* ELEMENTS specifically? I just Googled if the band wasn't from Greece - well, no. I'm obviously missing something here. I got out of this bind only by googling the actor.

It's a pity how this area of the grid spoiled my enjoyment of the whole thing - the theme was nice, the fill easy (maybe a bit too easy even).

Once again, it would be helpful to have this looked over by someone who is familiar with slang and modern vernacular

BRUH for "Dude!" does not make any sense
Minimum WAGE!
I implore anyone that found KIMBAP a difficult entry to try some: especially with some bulgogi, thinly sliced marinated beef. A great snack, and who knows, it might show up in a future puzzle :-)

A clever theme and a good EARTH day vibe with ‚ÄúGreen Day‚Äù, ‚ÄúEarth, Wind, and Fire‚Äù and the excellent "A fragile juxtaposition of land, oceans, and clouds,"

The motto this year‚Ä¶.. "Our Power, Our Planet".
What a terrific theme.  Each one was a little puzzle, and it was fun figuring out how to interpret them.  BASEBALL PLAYERS for [They Might be Giants] was the best!
Sam, I'd like you to know my daughter was the same with Weird Al. I took her to several concerts from county fairs to arenas.
This was fun! A bit challenging for a Tuesday (I felt, at least), but eminently solveable and a good theme.

Fun theme.

Am I the only one who hears 
a phrase and thinks,
‚Äúthat‚Äôd be a great name for a band‚Äù?

Chickadees look like bandit birds.
Ooh! The Bandit Birds!

I want my pizza cheese to be almost liquid.
Ooh! Liquid Cheese!

They‚Äôre never *good* and I‚Äôve long since
grown way too old to be in a band, 
and have *never* had the talent, so‚Ä¶

Just me?

You guys wanna start a band?
The Crucivibers?
The Word Nerds?

Anyone..?

Nice one Alex!
Happy Tuesday all!

Didn't know the Korean sushi rolls. I've never seen "Frozen," and probably never will. I saw "Giants" in the crossword of a New York newspaper and assumed football. FAT followed in the southwest corner. I thoght, somehow, that GREEnELEMENTS was correct (Earth day and all, I guess). I was about to be defeated by a Tursday puzzle.

But...Crest ads were drilled into my long-term  memory at an early age, so I can tell you, without looking it up, that "Crest has been shown to be an effective decay preventive dentifrice which can be of significant value when used in a conscientiously applied program of oral hygiene and regular professional care," and that the quote came from some journal associated with the  American Dental Association. So ADA went in, footBALL  became BASEBALL, I had enough quotes to see DIERESIS, and the rest filled in immediately.

The smell and taste of Crest toothpaste brings back vivid memories of a miserable childhood, though, and I never touch the stuff.
Great Tuesday puzzle. The wordplay was enjoyable without being contrived, a subtle but very important distinction for my personal enjoyment of the crossword. Thanks Alex!

What a great puzzle! Full of geography I knew, actors I didn't, and short fill which could have been drawn from a text book on logic or computer programming--ORS, NOT, MUSTS. I'm all with you Sam--if you're going to be pretentious enough to use those two dots, you should at least spell is "diaeresis," if not "di√¶resis." (That's ALT R-Z, if you care.) Two puzzle pairs, by co√Øncidence (OR NOT): From the wikipedia article on MINUET: "The name may refer to the short steps, pas MENUs, taken in the dance" (Hey! I just used [CTRL-V]!) MANCHA crossing [They Might Be Giants]--the band took its name from that of a 1971 film starring George C. Scott and Joanne Woodward, itself a reference to the windmill scene in Don Quixote de la Mancha! With a history of over 500 years, the Minuet has one of the longest staying power of any musical form, and there are thousands to choose from--the "Minuetto al Roverso" form the Haydn Symphony #47? Those slurs in Ravel's, from *Le Tombeau de Couperin*? Here's an English one, with *pas de menus* performed by an old friend from Cleveland: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=V-yoJfuysCc Finally, here's a song by a fave band, [Barker, Odenkirk, and others], appropriate to the day: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=HZ82EfFCyXg Happy Earth Day, everyone!

Does a zeppelin GAS UP?

Great name for a hot air balloon: Earth, Wind, and Fire.
Enjoyable!  While I ‚Äúgot‚Äù CAROLINAREAPERS for Red Hot Chili Peppers, I don‚Äôt actually ‚Äúget‚Äù it‚Ä¶

My favorite theme clue was [They Might Be Giants] because it was the least direct and it made me smile.

It sent me on a lovely rabbit hole, as I wondered about how that band came up with the name. Turns out it came from a 1971 film with the same name and that the film got the name from a Don Quixote passage about how Quixote mistook windmills for evil giants. (Wikipedia). (Hi, @Bill!)

Maybe the best part of the Wikipedia piece was that there is a book about how many famous bands got their names, and its title is ‚ÄúRock Formations‚Äù!

As for the puzzle, after I got two of the theme answers, there was great fun in guessing the remaining two.  I also liked DIERESIS crossing GREEK as the former comes from the latter.  It was poignant to see the lowly PEON in the bottom row.  And every name in the puzzle was of someone who turns my thumb up.

This puzzle, BTW, is brought to you by noun-or-verb clues: [Converse], [Fill at a station], [Grunt], [Anger].

Your puzzle, Alex, got me smiling and exploring in addition to solving.  What a splendid outing!  Thank you!

Great puzzle.  
I had never heard of the word DIERESIS (umlaut always worked for me).  
And CAROLINA REAPERS?  Was she a member of the Red Hot Chili Peppers?  That's no pun. (I was a little disappointed that this one didn't fit in with the rest of the theme.)  
However, my post puzzle research on these two words made me chuckle out loud.  
LOVED the theme. 
And I'm with Sheri and Sam on Wierd Al.
Thank you, Alex!  My Tuesday is starting off right...

I spent too much time trying to understand why the two dots in Bront√´ are a dieresis and not an umlaut and why it is there, given that the family was of Irish roots. 

Here's what Wikipedia has to say: 

At some point, Patrick Bront√´ (born Brunty), the sisters' father, decided on the alternative spelling with the diaeresis over the terminal ‚ü®e‚ü© to indicate that the name has two syllables.

My accomplishment today was instantly entering FROYO for 9A. I've stumbled over this one at least twice within recent memory.

Found this one easier than usual for a Tuesday, and the theme seemed a bit underwhelming to me. Especially GREEKELEMENTS for "Earth, Wind & Fire". The origins of the other band names were not directly related to the entries that went with them. For example, "Green Day" apparently refers to a a day spent smoking marijuana, and has nothing to do with the March holiday. And "They Might Be Giants" was taken from the title of the 1971 movie. But "Earth, Wind and Fire" was named for Maurice White's zodiacal elements, which are literally GREEKELEMENTS.

Anyway, there were some nice *words* in this grid: DIERESIS, SECULAR, SPHERE.

That said, we also got BRUH/BLAM.
Fun and fairly challenging for a Tuesday. Took 7m14s today.

I did not love this one because of the entire bottom third--no single egregious moment, but just a lot of not-so-hot-ones hanging out together and throwing themselves a mediocrity bash.  BRUH/BLAM almost requires crosses to resolve, as does AMER.  MARPLE was obscure to me (the only Agatha Christie detective I could come up with was POIROT), although I am sure a gimme for many.  Add in yet another "how do you spell IDINA?" moment.  Why not?  ADA seemed to me like crossword garbage compounded by a not great clue.  KIMBAP is obscure.  DIERESIS and SECULAR--okay, but not improved by the muddy crosses.  Unless I am missing something, the worst offender here is GREEK ELEMENTS, though. Was WATER like the Stu Sutcliffe or Pete Best of  EWF?

This was easily solved despite my not "getting" what was meant by some of the entries...well, one entry, anyway:  REAPERS.  (See below, responding to others' explanations.)

Very Tuesday-easy, but nothing harmless.

All of the Modern-day cartoon-movies can sink in the ocean, never to be seen again, and I will rejoice.  After "Snow White" it was all down-hill.

See all y'all tomorrow!

It's been over 60 years, and yet, whenever I hear the word "MINUET", my mind flashes to the theme song from "The Patty Duke Show":

"...where Cathy adores the minuet, 
the Ballet Russe, and cr√™pes Suzette, 
our Patty loves her rock 'n' roll; 
a hot dog makes her lose control..."

I suspect that it was in this lyric that I first heard about the Ballet Russe and cr√™pes Suzette, but it's the thought of Patty losing control over the hot dog that makes this line so memorable.

Not a lot of people know that IDINA Menzel planned on becoming a nun, until I sang to her, "Secular! I know about secular!"

Surprised nobody's linked to Weird Al's Cyndi Lauper inspired "Kimbap". 

Speaking of the Kit KAT Club, Larry David's in opinion today. I doubt the link would post.
Yall wild for having Grunt be that

BRUH! You got me with DIERESIS!ü§¶‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è ü§£
Knew the crosses, but was actually suprised by the gold star.
Have a good Tuesday!

Whe I was about 7 years old, I managed to check out an LP from the library by Cab Calloway. It was called "The Darktown Strutters Ball." I loved that record and the album art even more. My parents were alarmed at this, to this day I don't quite know why, but they begged me to give the record up.  No dice. I spent many happy hours listening to Minnie the Moocher on my parents high fi, the Heathkit that my uncle and my dad built. Now that thing embarrassed me.

I thought a diaresis mark was only used with two adjacent vowels to ensure separate syllable pronunciation, like na√Øve or da√Øs. Did the Bront√´ family just use it incorrectly when they should have chosen an acute and spelled it Bront√©?

Kind of a tough Tuesday for me, but managed to work it all out. One of those 'all in the clues' tricks. Just made for a nice challenge of getting enough down crosses to figure them out. Puzzle find today - a quite unusual one. A Wednesday from July 16, 2008 by Joe Krozel. Eight fifteen letter answers, all of them paired in a stack of two along each edge of the puzzle. And then: Eight two letter answers, each of those crossing those edge stacks - two on each edge. Here's the top edge answers: THREEMENINABOAT HORNSOFADILEMMA Here's the Xword Info link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=7/16/2008&g=2&d=D ...
Some tricky fill for a Tuesday but the crosses were pretty forgiving
AMER, BRUH, BLAM, LGA, SAO, YUP, MARPLE... 20 proper nouns... just an absolute slog. such a poor puzzle.
Loved the theme but wasn't a fan of the fill.
The NYT Crossword keeps on using the wrong term for an ‚ÄúSNL segment‚Äù.  The word is not SKIT, but rather SKETCH.  Sheesh!

Actresses with unusual names (AYO Edebiri) is one thing, but I have to draw the line at actresses with unusual names in animated movies, because you never see their faces. I know who did the voices for Buzz and Woody, because their voices are instantly recognizable, but IDINA Menzel? Who the heck is that? C'mon, man! On a Tuesday?

Almost fell at the GREEKELEMENTS/KIMBAP hurdle.

For Earth, Wind and Fire, all I kept thinking was Captain Planet! ü§¶üèæ‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è

Nancy J, Barry, Eric Hougland, and Mean Old Lady: I wanted to just quickly thank you for your considerate responses to my post on Saturday about the language we use to refer to system-impacted people. It's important to me, and I appreciated your willingness to engage. I was traveling at the time (on vacation!) and didn't have a chance to check for responses until it was too late to write a reply that you might see.

I think They Might Be Giants (1971) is a better film than Vincent Canby thought it was. What's not to like about Joanne Woodward and George C. Scott chewing the scenery together? Plus its a nice addition to the Sherlock Holmes pastiche genre, the best of which, to my mind, is Billy Wilder's The Private Life of Sherlock Holmes. TMBG also alludes to Saturday crosswords, though, as I recall, it was the Times of London's, not Canby's paper's. (I suspect you'll get more pleasure out of the movie if you ignore Scott's "British accent.")

Quality, challenging Tuesday puzzle, I really liked the theme answers. 
      Smallest of nits:  N.A. Stands for NOn-alcoholic, not NOT-alcoholic.
Pretty tough for a Tuesday. I thought it was Catalina Reapers and that messed me up. Wasn‚Äôt a fan of the bottom third with Amer, Bruh and Blam, Sao giving me trouble.

Another breezy grid. This week is shaping up to be a good one, crossword wise at least. Let‚Äôs forget about everything else shall we?

Ah the Bront√´s; scourge of a million forced school trips to nearby Haworth. Love the books, sick to death of the forced study. Also, I bizarrely wanted to write diacritic! 

Is it me or does anyone else shudder at the term BRUH? Such a horrible sound. YMMV.

Why is Let It Go so popular? I heard the song and it didn‚Äôt strike me as something beautiful or memorable. 

An unrelated note, Alicia Key‚Äôs whining song No One would make me physiologically stressed whenever I am at some place and it‚Äôs played on the radio.

This was awful. Amer? Gas up?
Come on‚Ä¶ why take money from non American subscribers and then fill the crossword with so many esoteric clues?

It's not even a dieresis! A dieresis is to indicate the two vowels in a dipthong are pronounced separately. An umlaut is to change vowel sounds, as in bront-ay sisters versus bront-ee sisters. Since Bront√´ doesn't have a dipthong, it can't have a dieresis
Tricky clues link is wrong
fun easy puzzle for a Tuesday! Love the work of Idina Menzel

Really, "dieresis" on a Tuesday? TIL a new word. by tomorrow, it will be forgotten, as it's never one I'll need.
I got it from the crossings and then looked up what it meant.

You know, if every puzzle was a favorite, having a favorite would be meaningless. This one wasn't a favorite of mine, though the last several of this constructor's puzzles did rank highly in my book and I'll continue to look forward to them! I like a puzzle to be challenging and this one just wasn't to me. Guess it was within my field of knowledge. And/or maybe I'm just not smart enough to be bothered by DIERESIS, which filled itself in but bothered others. üòÇ Also, I didn't find any humor in it... and I love me some humor words! By the time I did a full round of a cross and then down, practically everything was filled in. What was left of the themers made them very obvious to complete. Maybe I would have enjoyed them more if I had to think about them, but they seemed a little blah as a theme. Though I observe my time, I'm not motivated by it but this would have easily been a personal best (I was just a few seconds from it) had I not stopped to contemplate the following: 1) The Neil deGrassi Tyson quote, which I appreciated especially every day, but also on Earth Day! üòâ 2) Pondering how many in the comments would remark bout the SNL SKIT answer... it comes up every time. üòÅ 3) Remembering an episode of Star Trek TNG that features a sultry hologram named Minuet and a saxophone playing Riker. https://youtu.be/hoMJ-4AeayQ?si=RLkH3ypatOxVroNq üé∑üíÉ Besides, every day there's a puzzle is a good day! And today is a very beautiful day here in the Twin Cities!
"Secular" is a tune from Wicked, right?  "You're gonna be sec-yooo-ooh-lar..."  (More seriously, I don't love lay=secular.  Secular (as opposed to monastic) are clergy; laity are not.)
Did anyone else notice that Billie Joe Armstrong was not, in fact, walking alone in the video for "Boulevard of Broken Dreams?" üòÉ

Not to be overly diacritical, but a diaeresis marks two consecutive vowels that should be pronounced separately. (Eg. co√∂perate) Whereas an umlaut looks similar to a diaeresis, but it marks a single vowel as having a softer or shorter pronunciation. The Bront√´ family were descended from the Irish clan √ì Pronntaigh and their name was originally anglicized as Brunty, but Patrick Bront√´, father to Charlotte and Emily, changed the spelling, perhaps to better approximate the original Irish, perhaps to lend the family name a foreign mystique, or perhaps because he was an early fan of M√∂tley Cr√ºe. Either way, because it marked a single e, it is an umlaut and not a diaeresis, or if you prefer, a di√´resis.
Gimbap should never be romanized as Kimbap.
How is it not workS like a charm on the mini crossword??

@Liz B

Yes! Toward the end when I had GRaEg ELEMENTS I knew something was wrong.  It wasn't until I erased the A that the obvious GREEK emerged.
@Eddie ayo me too

@Hardroch
Why. Why would you sow more rancor and discontent into the world.
@Hardroch whoh this makes me want to challenge "Warren from Malta" to a cross-off! The gauntlet has been thrown!
@Kevin came here to say this, happy I wasn‚Äôt the only one.

@Joan
That was my happy-sound denier!! I guessed IDINA right, but was stuck on GREEn ELEMENTS for the longest time since nIMBAP seemed like a perfectly good name for a Korean dish lol

@Kevin

That was a horribly natick-y section.

I got stuck in that area too. Initially also had GREEn, but then could not figure how fire could be a green anything (literally or metaphorically), so it had to be something else.  
BIG didn‚Äôt occur to me straight away as ‚Äúmassive‚Äù feels bigger than plain ol‚Äô BIG. GAS UP is not in my idiolect as per my earlier comment (even though of course I know that you USians put ‚Äúgas‚Äù in your cars)
@Kevin I think I can guess, but what is a ‚ÄúNatick‚Äù? And where does the word come from? And why is it capitalized? Been wondering‚Ä¶

@Kevin

It‚Äôs funny because in theory I am all for making Monday-Wednesday harder.  

But then when I find myself running the alphabet on _imbap and di_resis it‚Äôs like someone stole my first born child.  TODAY IS TUESDAY I think to myself.  Am I really going to lose my close to a year streak on a Tuesday?

Thankfully not this week.

@Isabeau

The last of your pairs is a little too close to reality with all the tragic news stories over the years, including the recent Dominican concert.

@john ezra

NO MOSS for Rolling Stones

@Alexis Yes, I hear "gas up" a lot. Usually with an object (gas up the car) but also without. 

Leads sometimes to bean jokes, I'll admit...
@Alexis. Yup, I say it regularly.
@Alexis Younger people also ‚Äúgas up‚Äù their friends with positive reinforcement.

@Steve L

The first option on the Wawa app is "fuel up", but that's not what I'd be saying. My usual is "I've got to get gas (soon)".
Well there you go. Thanks for the responses folks

@john ezra I had greeb before Green before Greek mainly because I love bibimbap and that‚Äôs where my brain went first. I had the le of Marple so didn‚Äôt get caught there. And had the s in baseball before getting the whole clue.

@john ezra,
I had POIROT before MARPLE, and CUSPID before CANINE

@Mark Abe

The only thing I can cop to is POIROT before MARPLE. I also had GOON for Grunt before PEON, AUTO before AMER and BRAH before BRUH. To be honest I found the bottom half to be somewhat crunchy for a Tuesday

@john ezra I only missed the Poirot/Marple issue because I do acrosses before downs (at least first pass) and so had _A__L_. I'd left 64A as A__,  so didn't have the last letter, but that was enough. 

Otherwise I may have...

@Steve L

‚ÄúI wouldn't have expected GREEN in the answer after it had been featured prominently in the previous theme clue.‚Äù

I wouldn‚Äôt have expected EARTH at 19D when it‚Äôs prominently featured in a theme clue. 

Crossword blogs have warped my brain.

@Megan

I know bibimbap only from crosswords (though I expect I would enjoy it). I didn‚Äôt read carefully enough the clue for KIMBAP (which I hadn‚Äôt heard of before) and I ended up trying to find an error that turned out to be a B in square 44 instead of a K.

@Steve L, oops, I see the La____ now in the clue. Thanks for pointing that out!

Like SP, I also weighed (for the AAA clue) AUTO vs AMER and BROH-BRUH-BRAH...

@Eric Hougland

Good point!  I hadn't noticed.

@john ezra

I've seen BRUH, but not the other two.

@john ezra
I got KIM BAP immediately. There was a restaurant near my work that would serve bibim bap every Friday. There was always a huge line for it. But for some reason, they stopped serving it. There was almost a riot. People wanted that bibim bap.

"You can still get KIM BAP every day!" they told us.

It's not the same, dang it!

@Katie

If the 90s band Hanson opened a Korean restaurant, would you be able to get MMMBop?

@Steve L

I don‚Äôt remember what I came up with last night, but it wasn‚Äôt too difficult to take out EARTH and substitute something else. I think I found at least three options that would have worked.

@Steve L

Ha ha. It was another kind of green day today too. Our local dispensary celebrated with a 30% off sale.
@Steve L   Green Day solving to St Partricks emphasizes the green, and was the revealer for me.   Carolina reaper I had to get on crosses, as I am not familiar with it.

@Steve L

That would have been nice, but it'd be hard to pull that off without duplicating DAY.

@Beth

Your local sale was probably a carry-over from FOURTWENTY which could also be termed a "green day"

@Mtmetz

Yes, that's what it was.  I guess I was thinking it was still the 20th when I posted my comment... after partaking in some of the discountü™¥ü§£

@Whoa Nellie

@Camille Guigliano Umlauts and diereses look the same but function differently. Umlauts change the pronunciation of a single vowel, while diereses divide the pronunciation of two vowels. Sometimes a dieresis replaces a hyphen, if that helps, as in The New Yorker‚Äôs co√∂p for co-op.
@Camille Guigliano a Caroline Reaper is a variety of extremely hit chili pepper. It does fit with the rest of the theme.

@Xword Junkie

I don‚Äôt get the objection to the band name clues. 

The answers are just alternative meanings for the well-known band names but have no connection to the bands themselves. 

So Earth, Wind and Fire, Red Hot Chili Peppers, Green Day and They Might Be Giants are all names of bands but the answers are possible other answers if they weren‚Äôt band names but instead regular clues. 

So aside from being names of bands‚Ä¶

Earth Wind and Fire are three of the four ancient Greek conceptions of the Elements that make up matter. 

Carolina Reapers are a variety of red hot chili peppers. 

St. Patrick‚Äôs Day has a strong association with the colour green. 

They Might Be Giants could be a reference to the players on the Major League Baseball team that has its home in San Francisco.

@Hardroch I see it there in the M-W entry, but every other result, including an article on M-W that describes the diaresis, as well as the entries and articles about it from OED, Grammarly, Cambridge Dictionary, Britannica, Oxford Reference, several articles from here in the NYT over the years, and many others, specify pretty clearly that it only applies to adjacent vowels.
